Hi there!  The City of Ann Arbor rolled this out a few years ago.  We spent some time on the policy and a communication plan.  We met with departments and the main concern was the stipend is taxable.  We incorporated that into the the amount of the stipend.  I am happy to share all of our information with you.  My number is 734-794-6512 or you can email me.

answers.author: Jay Gsell
answers.text:
presently we have a myriad of cell phones and air cards within our verizon total minutes package that are both assigned to individuals and are general staff /on call devices that various staff rotate use of. The phones also run the gamut of basic to smart/Iphone  technology. my self I have never asked the County to pay for or provide me with a wireless device and I purchased and pay for my Iphone with Verizon in a family plan that provides a Gov employee 19% discount on  monthly charges. My county email is synced with my phone and my phone number is disclosed on a case by case basis for business commun ication and is known to all my Dept heads, County Legislators and key support staff.For me this is the price of doing my job and using today's technology but not thinking that everything has to be paid for or covered by my public employer and I refuse to have a business and personal wireless device that I have to carry or put on a " belt " like my EMS and law enforcement people wear to carry guns , tasers , pagers , cell phones and the occassional" bat phone".

answers.author: Troy Brown
answers.text:
The City of Livermore moved to a stipend about 18 months ago.  We provide varying levels of stipends, dependent upon anticipated usage.  There are phone only stipends (50 per month) and phone/data stipends (90 per month).
We really involved the employees in helping drafting the policy, and provided a lot of data as to the anticipated savings.  More importantly, we explained "why" early in the process. 
It's a lot to describe in a posting, but i'd be more than happy to talk with you about the trials and tribulations of moving forward.  I can give you a copy of the policy and talk with you if you'd like.  I can be reached at 925.960.4000.  Good luck!

answers.author: Michael Walker
answers.text:
Our approach in Brentwood, Tennessee is similar for eligible employees: $40 a month for cell phones, $60 with data features.  What sold our employees on the change over about 4 years ago was that phone records for City owned phones are public records under state law in Tennessee. It eliminates the "got you" type articles directed at incidental personal calls being made by employee on City provided phones, etc. The additional taxable income was the trade-off but well worth it.

author: Leslie Beauregard
text:
I know that several localities have begun offering stipends to employees who use their own personal phones for City business, such as email, etc.  In my case, I gave up my City issued Blackberry and purchased my own I-Phone which has my City email account included.  For those who have gone in this direction, how did you move this idea forward?  What push back did you receive and how was it overcome?  Did you only allow those with localitiy issued phones who will willing to give those up to take advantage of this? How did you determine a stipend amount?
Thanks for your help!
title: Stipends for Personal Cell Phone Use for City Business
